column2: A guard of Italian Grenadiers was drawn up last Friday morning at the railroad station in the Italian border town of Brennero. Benito Mussolini, 57, and for eighteen years dictator of Italy, was on the red-carpeted station platform.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5--The next year will bring the largest increase in employment this country has ever witnessed in a like period, with jobs for 5,000,000 to 6,000,000 persons, Secretary Perkins predicted today on the basis of a report made to her by the Labor Department's Bureau of Labor Statistics.

After having dispensed with its annual meeting last Fall, the American Academy of Arts and Letters will return this year to its former practice of holding a formal meeting in November at its building at 633 West 155th Street. The date set for the ceremonies is Nov. 14.

By rising $50,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday to $6,870,000,000, the excess reserves of member banks of the Federal Reserve System, on the basis of figures revealed yesterday, came within $10,000,000 of duplicating the high record established in the week ended on July 17. With three days more to run the National Automobile Show drew increasing response yesterday from car-minded visitors as exhibitors sought the consumer's approval. The show closes Sunday night.

Opinions in the advertising field conflict sharply on the question as to whether the new tax bill designed to curb excessive war profits will benefit advertising, reports yesterday indicated. The Securities and Exchange Commission's request for repeal of the New York Stock Exchange's multiple trading rule reached New York so late yesterday that it prevented comment by the latter body.

Having tapered off with a long drill on the attack yesterday, Columbia's undefeated football team is ready for what Coach Lou Little considers its severest test so far this season. The Lions will meet Syracuse tomorrow at Baker Field.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24--Secretary of Labor Perkins announced today that 600,000 more persons were employed in September than the previous month. By next September, said Mias Perkins, some 6,000,000 additional workers will be employed and by that time not much will be left of the unemployment situation.

Wood, general credit manager of the Johns-Manville Corporation.

The rapidly mounting total of excess reserves of member banks of the Federal Reserve System rose $70,000,000 in the week ended Wednesday to a new high record at $6,940,000,000, according to figures revealed yesterday.

LONDON, Friday, Oct. 25--Stars shone over London the past night from a beautifully clear sky. It was the sort of weather that seemed made for the German raiders; but after a sharp attack during the first part of the night the capital had a comparatively quiet time.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 24--Production of war planes in the United States for defense and for British requirements has been speeded up Secretary Morgenthau said today at his press conference.

A gain of one percentage point for Wendell L. Willkie in New York State was reported yesterday by Dr. George Gallup, director of the American Institute of Public Opinion, as a result of a survey conducted between Oct. 14 and Oct. 22. President Roosevelt, with 51 per cent of the voters interviewed to 49 for the Republican candidate, now leads by only 2 per cent.

Wendell L. Willkie is a two-to-one favorite over President Roosevelt among the students at St. John's College, Brooklyn, according to a survey published yesterday in The Torch, weekly student newspaper.

Regulations governing the granting of time for religious instruction to pupils in the New York City school system were issued yesterday by the Board of Superintendents. Under the proposed rules, the last hour of school session each Wednesday has been set apart for religious training.

MERCERSBURG, Pa., Oct. 24-- Fido Kempton's face is radiating happiness again. CHICAGO, Nov. 10--The market for corn for future delivery was helped last week by a steadier tone in the cash market, liberal shipping sales and the implications of inflation that affected other grains also.

CHICAGO, Nov. 10--For this season, Winter wheat conditions are regarded as satisfactory, taking the belt as a whole. Rain is needed in the western end of the belt, especially in the western third of Kansas and parts of the Texas Panhandle.

Fired by the die-for-dear-old-Rutgers spirit that once placed college football in a class by itself, the Brookln Dodgers climbed the inspirational heights before a record gathering of 33,846 at Ebbets Field yesterday and administered to the seemingly invincible Washington Redskins their first defeat of the National League season.
AN EASTERN CANADIAN PORT, Nov. 10 (UP)--Passengers arriving here tonight from England told of attacks by bombers, a surface raider and a submarine while en route to Canada.

ROME, Nov. 10--General Ubaldo Soddu, Under-Secretary for War, has replaced General Sebastiano Visconti Prasca as commander in chief of the Italian troops in Albania, it was announced today.

LONDON, Nov. 10--There has been little active speculative reaction to the United States Presidential election, although intense interest has been taken in the event, which as never before has been of such importance to Britain.

Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., won yesterday the award of $800,000 of current expense obligations of the city of Pittsburgh, Pa., at 0.23 per cent, plus a premium of $20.50. The issue, dated Nov. 1, 1940, will mature on Nov. 1, 1941.

The 10,000 Associated Willkie Clubs throughout the country are planning to continue in operation and become a vital part of the "loyal opposition" which Wendell L. Willkie called for in his radio address to the nation Monday night, Oren Root Jr., head of the clubs, announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12--Mr. Willkie made an important, thoughtful and patriotic speech over the radio last night between 10:30 and 11 o'clock. The time and occasion were well advertised. Mr. Willkie was addressing the more than twenty-two millions of American citizens who voted for him last week, in acknowledgment of the receipt of thousands of inquiries from this larger than a 45 per cent minority their general tenor being, "What do we do now?"

The great 85,000-ton liner Queen Elizabeth, the largest and probably the fastest in the world, sailed out of New York harbor last night to join the company of merchant ships that have preceded her in His Majesty's service.

LONDON, Nov. 12--The British Admiralty announced tonight that nine ships were missing from a convoy of thirty-eight merchant vessels that had been attacked by a German raider in mid-Atlantic exactly a week ago. Freschi in General Sessions to twenty-three prison terms of three to six years each, to run concurrently.

Harbord, chairman of the New York Chapter, speaking over radio station WJZ as a feature of the current roll-call campaign for funds.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, Nov. 12-- Opinion continued to suggest today that the most vital point of the Molotoff-Hitler discussions will be Turkey. The Philadelphia Orchestra, led by Eugene Ormandy, paid a lively visit at Carnegie Hall last night. It was the second visit of the season and it found the orchestra in fine fettle. Mr. Ormandy presented a program in which he did his best work, and his soloists were equal to the evening's high standards. It added up to a satisfying, often stirring, concert.

Short interest in New York Stock Exchange stocks on Oct. 31 was 530,442 shares, compared with the corrected total of 517,713 for Sept. 30. Neither total includes short positions in the odd-lot accounts of odd-lot dealers, which were 47,730 shares on Oct. 31 and 61,063 on Sept. 30.

George F. Chapline, vice president in charge of sales of the Wright Aeronautical Corporation, resigned that post yesterday to become president and general manager of the Brewster Aeronautical Corporation. He has been identified with the Wright organization in various capacities since 1929.

Directors of the Western Union Telegraph Company declared yesterday the first dividend on the company's capital stock in more than three years. The dividend, $1 a share, is payable on Dec. 16 to holders of record of Nov. 22. The last dividend, 75 cents a share, was paid on July 15, 1937.

The Museum of Modern Art, 11 West Fifty-third Street, opened with a private view last night two exhibitions, one of them surveying the career of Frank Lloyd Wright, the other that of D.W. Griffith. CAIRO, Egypt, Nov. 17--The Royal Air Force announced today that British planes had attacked Brindisi, Italy, again yesterday morning. HERSHEY. Pa., Nov. 17--Dr. Raymond Pearl, noted biologist and statistician, who was an authority on changes in world populations, died this morning of a coronary thrombosis at the Hotel Hershey, to which he and Mrs. Pearl had brought a party of guests from Baltimore for the week-end. His age was 61.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 17--The volume of steel business booked by the nation's steel mills in the first seventeen days of this month has been running substantially ahead of the corresponding October period. CHICAGO, Nov. 17 (AP)--Jimmy Wilson, catcher-coach of the Cincinnati Reds, has been offered the managership of the Cubs and is expected to sign a contract tomorrow in a conference with Owner Philip K. Wrigley.

There will be no interruption of service on the city's unified transit system because of the controversy between the Board of Transportation and the Transport Workers Union, Mayor La Guardia declared yesterday upon his return from his trip to the Pacific Coast as chairman of the United States-Canadian Defense Commission.

LONDON, Nov. 17--Important changes were announced tonight in the organization of the High Command of the Royal Air Force. WASHINGTON, Nov. 17--Lumber consumption for 1940 will total about 28,500,000,000 feet, or 8 per cent above 1939, according to an estimate in the fourth quarter survey made by the Lumber Survey Committee for the Department of Commerce.

Wholesale market business was generally only fair last week, but cold weather in many sections resulted in a rush of orders for Winter outerwear and purchasing of gift items held to the previous week's levels.

Britons who died fighting in the World War were honored yesterday afternoon by comrades in arms who survived them, at the annual Service of Remembrance of the New York branch of the British Great War Veterans of America in St. Thomas Protestant Episcopal Church, Fifth Avenue and Fiftythird Street.

CHICAGO, Nov. 17--Inflation talk and removal of hedges by mills against flour sales kept the price of wheat on the upgrade the greater part of the last week, with the December delivery touching 90 cents a bushel at one time, a new high level for any contract since last, May, while the May and July futures went into new seasonal ground.

AMSTERDAM, Nov. 17--Last week's Continental markets showed no uniform trend, each being guided by its own national influences. It was noteworthy, however, that almost everywhere bonds showed a firm tendency.

LONDON, Monday, Nov. 18-- Royal Air Force bombers subjected the German-held Channel coast of France to a renewed heavy pounding during the past night, following daylight attacks on the "invasion ports" yesterday.

LONDON, Monday, Nov. 18--The German Air Force started the eleventh week of the "Battle of Britain" yesterday by raiding a coastal town and the sea-borne trade of this island kingdom. In a Thanksgiving Day greeting to county chairmen, Edward F. Jaeckle, Republican State chairman, said yesterday there was a "steady and consistent Republican resurgence" under way in New York. PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 18--While the public still clamored for tickets, all of which were disposed of four days ago, the Penn football team today held one of its longest drills of the season to tighten its defense against passes for the Cornell encounter next Saturday at Franklin Field.

St. George's Memorial House at 207 East Sixteenth Street will be transformed into the setting of "Ye Olde New England Village" for the fourth annual Christmas bazaar of St. George's Protestant Episcopal Church, to be held on Dec. 5 and 6. Many diversions have been planned for the occasion.

FORT McCLELLAN, Ala., Nov. 18--New York City's 165th Infantry completing its record fire practice with the new Garand automatic rifle this afternoon as the Twentyseventh Division, having finished its first two full weeks of training, went on to realistic combat practice.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18--An indication that the trip to Mexico of Henry A. Wallace, Vice Presidentelect, might be more than a visit of official courtesy emerged today when Mr. Wallace discussed his plans to attend the inauguration of Mexican President-elect Manuel Avila Camacho with President Roosevelt.
AT A SECRET BRITISH AIR BASE, in the Mediterranean, Nov. 18--I was on a British bombing raid over Brindisi, Italy, the other night.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 18--A British opportunity is passing because of lack of strength to exploit it.

TOKYO, Tuesday, Nov. 19--Heavy fighting is going on in the jungles along the Thailand-Annam borders, where Thailand has mobilized 100,000 men, according to information that the radical nationalist newspaper Yomiuri says that it has received from reliable sources in Bangkok.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Nov. 18 (AP)-- Ernest E. Cole, State Education Commissioner, praised American teachers tonight for training the ablest and most efficient citizenry of any country and any age while being "grossly underpaid."

The Sadie and Arthur Lamport Foundation, Inc., 44 Pine Street, receives a bequest of $150,000 under the will of its founder, Arthur Matthew Lamport, which was filed for probate in Surrogate's Court yesterday. Mr. Lamport, who was an investment banker, philanthropist and economist, died at his home in the Lombardy, 111 East Fifty-sixth Street, on Nov. 8.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Nov. 18 (AP)--Brig. Gen. Robert L. Eichelberger, 54, one of the youngest of his rank, today became the thirtyeighth Superintendent of the Military Academy. He succeeds Major Gen. Jay L. Benedict, who is to command the new Fourth Army Corps at Camp Blanding, Fla.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18--The Panhandle Eastern Pipe Line Company of Kansas City, Mo., filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering issuance of $18,250,000 of bonds and $5,000,000 of serial notes.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18--The Reconstruction Finance Corporation and the Securities and Exchange Commission both announced today that they would take steps to facilitate defense financing.

READING M.W. Fodor's "The Revolution Is On"* makes me wonder whether it wouldn't be a good idea if our writers went a little easy with the word "treason," especially in connection with conquered Belgium, the Netherlands and France. The word itself means something pretty definite, and may as well be handled accordingly. There have been cases of fatal treason in past...

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Nov. 18 --Italian bombers were guilty of the raid on Bitolj [Monastir] and Southern Yugoslavia on Nov. 5 and the Italian Government has agreed to pay indemnity for the nineteen killed and thirty-three wounded, as well as all material damages, according to a government communique tonight.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Nov. 18-- Michael Staksrud, former world's champion skater, whose body was found in a lake near Oslo, Norway, following his disappearance after a Quislingist meeting, was murdered, it is establashed.

FORT DEVENS, Mass., Nov. 18 --The Army's No. 1 rookie under the nation's first peacetime conscription left a civilian life of jobhunting today for a year in uniform after being advised that service in the Army was as good--or as tough --"as you make it."

A funeral service for Earle Bailie, investment banker who served the government as "dollar-a-year" adviser in emergency, was held yesterday morning in St. George's Protestant Episcopal Church, 207 East Sixteenth Street.

The price of turkey for Thanksgiving dinner will range from 25 to 39 cents a pound, and Thanksgiving dinner will cost less this year than it has at any time since 1933, the depth of the depression, the Consumers Service of the Department of Markets said yesterday. Chain store turkey prices were made public today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 (AP)--In scattered communities from New England to the Pacific Coast little groups of men raised their right hands today, swore to bear "true faith and allegiance" to the United States, and became soldiers under the nation's first peacetime selective military service program.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18--The Commonwealth and Southern Corporation and the Tennessee Utilities Corporation and the Tennessee Electric Power Company, its subsidiaries, have filed an application with the Securities and Exchange Commission seeking approval of the liquidation of the Tennessee Power Company.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Nov. 18 --John L. Lewis swept aside a "draft" movement of tumultuous proportions today and disclosed to the delegates of the convention of the Congress of Industrial Organizations his determination to retire as president of the organization in a few days.

The State of Alabama will be in the market on Dec. 3 with an issue of $868,000 of bridge refunding bonds, for which bidders are asked to name a rate of interest not exceeding 2 per cent. The bonds, dated Dec. 1, 1940, will mature serially on Dec. 1, 1941 to 1955.

SARASOTA, Fla., Nov. 18--Dr. Henry Hurd Rusby, who was Professor of Botany, Physiology and Materia Medica, Department of Pharmacy, Columbia University, from 1888 to 1930, died here tonight at his home, where he had been living in retirement for several years. His age was 85.

ROME Nov. 18--In his first public speech since Italy's entry into the war Premier Mussolini today painted a glowing picture of Italian achievements during five months of fighting. He told the people that victory was already within the grasp of the Axis.

Continuing their statistical spree, the Washington Redskins last Sunday wrote another record into the National Football League book by raising their season's total of pass completions to 131 with thirteen successful tosses against the Chicago Bears, according to the official figures released yesterday.

German is rapidly losing its popularity in the New York City school system, fewer students taking it now than at any time in the last ten years, it was reported yesterday by Dr. Theodore Huebener, acting director of foreign languages.

LONDON, Nov. 18-Eric Gill, a sculptor, died yesterday at an Uxbridge nursing home at the age of 58. He had been ill several months. Four years ago he designed his own tombstone, the inscription on which asks stoneworkers to remember him.

Jim Crowley took advantage of yesterday's brisk weather and sent the Ram football squad through a two-hour drill on Fordham Field in preparation for the game with the Arkansas Razorbacks Thursday afternoon at the Polo Grounds.

A banking group headed by A.C. Allyn Co., Inc., will offer today to the public $3,000,000 of first-mortgage 5 per cent bonds and $2,000,000 of first-mortgage 3 per cent serial bonds of the Atlantic Company, Atlanta, Ga. Both issues will be priced at par and accrued interest.

CHICAGO. Nov. 18--Wheat showed a firm undertone in the early trading today with the July selling at new seasonal high level.

Miss Anna Jay Pierrepont, the last of her generation in one of New York's oldest families, died of a heart attack on Sunday at her home, 1 Pierrepont Place, Brooklyn, where she was born 79 years ago.
LYON, France, Nov. 18--"I accept your oath, I return it to France, whom we have sworn to serve and to save. I myself renew that oath together with you."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18--A return of only 3.2 per cent on the total average capital of $294,189,327 employed before deduction of interest on long-term borrowings and income taxes is reported for 1939 by the Federal Trade Commission for the four most important concerns specializing in coke-oven products.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Nov. 18 (UP)--National Herrerista party members of Congress reiterated today firm opposition to creation of naval bases in Uruguay in cooperation with the United States and thus brought to a head the Cabinet crisis created by the resignation of Turibio Olasso, Minister of Public Instruction.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18--Great Britain and the United States have agreed upon the exact sites for American land-plane, seaplane and naval bases on seven of the eight New World islands and continental areas involved in the trade of fifty American destroyers for British bases completed and announced by President Roosevelt on Sept. 3.
The New York Social Register for 1941, now being distributed to its subscribers, contains few changes in its listing of prominent families in this city.

Growing opposition among the population of Belgium to the German military occupation is roported in messages just received in prominent circles here, it was learned yesterday. They said that this opposition had a striking demonstration recently in Antwerp, where the Germans ordered all Jews to wear the six-pointed star of the shield of David on their arms.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22--Rear Admiral William D. Leahy, retired, Governor of Puerto Rico and former Chief of Naval Operations, has been selected as Ambassador to France, according to authoritative information today. Word of his acceptability to the Vichy government is expected momentarily.

MUNICH, Germany, Nov. 22-- Opening the Congress of the Academy for German Law in Munich today, the Justice Commissioner, Dr. Hans Frank, the head of this institution, dropped some significant hints as to the future legal structure of the "New Europe" that is being drafted under German leadership by the Axis powers.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 22--The Black Diamond Steamship Company has applied to the Maritime Commission for permission to sell eight of its ships to British interests.

Everything is in readiness for the third annual dinner and revue of the New York Financial Writers Association, known as the Financial Follies of 1940, which will be held in the hotel Astor on Friday evening, Nov. 29, at 7:30 o'clock.

The fanatical gleam in alumni eyes for the last two months is about due to disappear and football is ready to enter into the strictly conversational stage. For today is the final day of the campaign for all except a few laggards.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22--Announcement of the establishment in London of an American Gifts Committee to coordinate requests and regulate shipments of relief supplies from the United States was welcomed here today by Norman H. Davis, chairman of the American Red Cross.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 22-- Melvyn Douglas and Conrad Veidt will play the male leads with Joan Crawford in Metro's "A Woman's Face," the studio announced today. James Stewart previously had been scheduled for one of the roles.

NEW KENSINGTON, Pa., Nov 22 (AP)--A dispute over one worker precipitated today a plant-wide strike at the New Kensington works of the Aluminum Company of America, where aviation, Army and other defense materials were being produced.
WASHINGTON. Nov. 22--Internal revenue collections in October registered a 21 per cent increase over October, 1939, Treasury figures indicated today.
The question of whether increased power in the Federal Government would destroy individual liberty and lead to dictatorship was debated yesterday by four leaders in addresses over WJZ.

Responding to efforts by representatives of the industry to preserve the company as an important unit in the dress field, officials of the C.H.D. Robbins Company said yesterday they had reconsidered their decision to liquidate and announced that the company would remain in business.

A substantial majority of American voters favor sending more planes to England, even though it might delay our own national defense program, a nation-wide survey by the American Institute of Public Opinion has revealed, according to Dr. George Gallup, its director.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., Nov. 22-- Frank W. Murphy, farm leader and attorney, died today at the age of 71. A Republican, he shifted to Al Smith in 1928 and remained a Democrat until 1940, when he supported Wendell Willkie.

SYRACUSE Nov. 22--The National Grange today indorsed a twoprice plan for agricultural products, a compromise aimed to meet objections from Eastern areas.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 22--In its final test before next Saturday's heavy date with Navy, an under-dog Army eleven will meet Princeton before a crowd of 25,000 in Palmer Stadium tomorrow afternoon. It will be the final contest of the 1940 season for the Tigers.

Twenty-one of the forty-one divisions of volunteers canvassing Manhattan and the Bronx in the New York Red Cross chapter's annual roll-call were reported yesterday to be ahead of their 1939 records for the first half of the campaign. The roll-call began on Nov. 11 and will continue until Nov. 30. The chapter's goal this year is $375,000 to help carry on domestic operation of the American Red Rross.

BERLIN, Nov. 22--General Ion Antonescu, head of the new totalitarian Rumanian state, accompanied by his Foreign Minister, Prince Costin Sturza and numerous other functionaries arrived in Berlin this morning for a three-day visit at the invitation of the Reich Government.

The New York State Labor Relations Board made public yesterday a statistical summary showing that from July 1, 1937 to Oct. 31, 1940, the total number of cases of all types filed with the board had been 6,441 of which 5,792 had been closed, leaving 699 pending.
Comment generally made on the course of commodity prices in this country has been that the advance, in connection with the war, the war orders and our own defense plans, has been conservative.

This afternoon at 4 o'clock the West Forty-seventh Street station house will go out of existence. Its history, dating from Jan. 1, 1862, at 6 A. M., to today is the story of midtown New York from gas-lit, cobbled streets to monstrous, animated electric signboards.

New State and municipal financing scheduled for sale next week by forty municipalities aggregates $31,512,040, compared with only $7,801,535 for this week. The weekly average of offerings for the year to date now stands at $30,894,395.

Koritza, principal Italian base within Albanian territory for the invasion of Greece, has at last fallen. Rome admits that the town is in Greek hands. This is a suitable triumph for Greek arms. Argyrokastron, the second Italian base, a little more to the westward, is now under attack.

ISTANBUL, Turkey. Nov. 22--Following a long Cabinet session tonight, martial law and a state of siege were proclaimed in most of European Turkey and regions of Asia minor bordering on the Bosporus and Dardanelles. The state of siege is effective immediately and is decreed for one month.

Reports from two British freighters in widely separated parts of the Atlantic Ocean indicated yesterday that two German surface raiders might be roaming the Atlantic.

LONDON, Nov. 24--Enemy planes were over Britain again tonight. They dropped bombs on widely separated areas. It is doubtful, however, whether they did as much damage to the British cause as the censorship, which now is in full bloom of the silly season.

LONDON, Monday, Nov. 25-- Enemy raiders during the past night turned their attention from London and the Midlands to the West Country, where a town was heavily attacked for several hours. Casualties were reported in accounts early today.

The reported proposal to halt the production of commercial transport planes in the United States to make factory room for defense orders produced yesterday a mixed reaction among leaders in the commercial field. All officials queried refused to talk "on the record." None of them, as they phrased it, wanted "to get in bad with the War Department."

FORT BENNING, Columbus, Ga., Nov. 24--An Army city, $11,000,000 worth of it, is springing up out of the red clay and long-leafed pines of Georgia, a tour of the 97,000acre reservation of the Infantry School revealed today.

Basketball will make its 1940-41 debut at Madison Square Garden tonight when the Phillips 66 Oilers of Bartlesville, Okla., the National A.A.U. champions, oppose the Ohrbach A.A., metropolitan A.A.U. titleholder for the past two years.

Once in a while even Nature turns out something with her left hand, and one of her mistakes brought considerable worry to David Murray Jr. of Glenmount, N.Y., who shot a fine 16-point buck last week, only to find that it was a doe.

CHICAGO, NOV. 24--For a third straight year, Forest Evashevski and Tom Harmon of Michigan have been placed on the Western Conference all-star football team selected annually by conference coaches for The Associated Press.
VICHY, Nov. 24--The laws and decrees now being published constitute the application of the principals on which is based the government's policy, which is largely social in its nature.

Greece may be defeated, but she will never be conquered, the Rev. Dr. David de Sola Pool declared yesterday at a special service in the Spanish and Portuguese Synagogue, Central Park West at Seventieth Street, for the "suffering people of Greece."

College football put on its last complete show on Saturday. For most of the nation's young wearers of the moleskin and cleats, the hopes and aches and disappointments of the season of 1940 are now history, to be cherished among their most prized souvenirs, regardless of the vicissitudes of fortune.

YONKERS, N.Y., Nov. 24--Lieut. Gov. Charles Poletti, addressing an audience of 1,000 at a Polish patriotic rally in the Polish Community Center here tonight, declared that "this celebration is a sure sign that the Polish will to live as a free nation cannot be permanently crushed."

ROME, Nov. 24--Pope Pius XII, like millions of other Catholics throughout the world this morning, raised his voice in a prayer for the dead and for those who are suffering as a consequence of the great war.

Notching all of their goals in a thrill-jammed third period, the New York Rovers handed the Washington (D.C.) Eagles their first Eastern Hockey League setback, 4 to 3, before 10,000 onlookers in the star attraction of an amateur doubleheader at Madison Square Garden yesterday afternoon.

Carl Storck, president of the National Football League, acting on a protest from Dan Topping, owner of the Dodgers, ruled last night that the game between the Philadelphia Eagles and the Pittsburgh Steelers had been postponed indefinitely.

Reporting today to stockholders for the fiscal year of fifty-three weeks ended on Aug. 31, Harry M. Warner, president of Warner Brothers Pictures, Inc., says the gross income, after eliminating intercompany transactions, was $100,337,092, compared with $102,083,131 for the fiscal year of fifty-two weeks ended on Aug. 26, 1939.

Peace will not be achieved by men in military uniform, but by "men on their knees in the sackcloth and ashes of penance," the Rev. Joseph F. Flannelly, administrator of St. Patrick's Cathedral, declared in his sermon at solemn mass there yesterday. Father Flannelly called upon the congregation to observe strictly the Pope's command to make the day a period of prayer and mortification for peace.

SOFIA, Bulgaria, Nov. 24 (AP)-- German circles openly predicted tonight that Bulgaria "in a very short time" would not only sign up with the Axis but also "seize the golden opportunity to obtain an outlet to the Aegean from Greece." Such a move might turn Bulgaria into a battlefield.

AMSTERDAM, Nov. 24--Dutch interest in United States stocks has fallen off, but still is intrinsically keen, though generally more of a speculative than an investment character, because of the uncertainty regarding dividend transfers and the ultimate dollar-guilder ratio.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24--Hugh Robert Wilson, who entered the United States diplomatic service in 1911 as private secretary to the American Minister in Lisbon and rose to be Assistant Secretary of State and Ambassador to Germany, has retired, it was announced today, by the State Department.
ELMIRA, N.Y., Nov. 24 (AP)-- Stanley W. Smith of North Tonawanda made four flights in his allmetal, two--passenger motorless plane today to capture the second annual Snowbird Soaring Championship.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24--A nation-wide investigation of trade restraints which, exercised by middlemen, increase prices to the consumer and reduce the prices received by the farmer way announced today by the anti-trust division of the Justice Department.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Nov. 24-- Oslo police announced today the discovery of a most important gasoline swindle in which many leading Quislingists [followers of Major Vidkun Quisling, head of the Nazicontrolled government] seem to be involved.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 24 (AP)-- The man who owns San Francisco Chinatown's new motion-picture theatre and sometimes serves as usher too, just to keep things running smoothly, is Joseph Sunn, president of the Grandview Film Company of Hongkong, and a pioneer in the production of Chinese movies.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24--Unique in the United States, a midnight mass was celebrated last night in the Shrine of the Immaculate Conception in the Catholic University here and was followed continuously by a serias of low masses until 10 o'clock this morning.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 24--A further heavy influx of miscellaneous steel orders, a continuation of substantial export support, moderatesized railroad buying, a half-point gain in steel ingot production and stronger scrap markets featured news of the steel industry last week.

CHICAGO, Nov. 24 (AP)--Toronto's pace-setting Maple Leafs, their fivegame winning streak snapped twenty-four hours earlier by Chicago, came back tonight to whip the Black Hawks, 4 to 2, in a National Hockey League battle.
Mr. and Mrs. O'Donnell Iselin will give a tea tomorrow at their home, 104 East. Seventy-first Street, to introduce to their friends their daughter, Miss Emilie O'Donnell Iselin.

MEXICO CITY, Nov. 24--With the end of President Lazaro Cardenas's six-year-term of office next Sunday, when General Manuel Avila Camacho will assume Executive office. Ignacio Garcia Tellez, Minister of the Interior, made a broadcast address tonight, on "Six Years of Government at the Service of Mexico."

Lehman Brothers, Goldman, Sachs Co. and the First Boston Corporation head an underwriting group which will offer today to the public 140,591 shares of Indianapolis Power and Light Company 5 per cent cumulative preferred stock of $100 par value.

LONDON, Nov. 24--Lord Tryon, who, as Major George Clement Tryon, was Postmaster General from 1935 until his resignation last April, a veteran of the South African and World Wars, died of a heart attack today at his home.

AMSTERDAM, Nov. 24--Continental European markets were influenced last week by Axis diplomatic activity and military developments. Early in the period the Bourses marked time. New York's disappointing trend affected adversely most stocks.

The six finalists in the annual tournament for the individual championship of the Interscholastic Chess League and six participants in the consolation contest, which will run concurrently, were determined yesterday, when postponed games were played off at the Marshall Chess Club.

Five properties in Brooklyn were sold by the Chase National Bank, as trustee of the estate of Sarah E. Spence, in a deal reported over the week-end. The parcels were sold free and clear of mortgages to the Seaboard Investing Corporation, representing George M. Mayer and Samuel Hurwitz, through Clinton W. Blume, broker.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24--National defense projects now account for about one-fifth of the entire Works Progress Administration program and take precedence over all other projects, Howard O. Hunter, acting WPA Administrator, said today.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Nov. 24-- R.H. Bertram and Bob De Coppettied for first in Class B, Scotty Isdale won in Class X and H.G. Herbert came through in the 110 Class in the weekly sailing dinghy races at the Larchmont Yacht Club today.

The Rev. Dr. John Sutherland Bonnell told his congregation yesterday morning that human history unites with divine revelation in proclaiming that injustice and oppression house the seeds of their own destruction.

Miss Elizabeth F. Nammack, former chairman of the Department of Classical Languages at Wadleigh High School, a retired school teacher who had served in the New York City school system for fifty-one years, died early Saturday morning ...

CAIRO, Egypt. Nov. 24--Although Metemma still is not occupied by the British, that Sudanese outpost opposite Gallabat has been practically evacuated by the Italians, who found the continued pounding by British artillery and harassing British patrols too much for them, the British Command announced today.

VICHY, Nov. 24--Negotiations continuing with Germany have had some indirect result in the financial domain. Improvement in the system of sending funds from one zone to the other, already announced, has been supplemented by another measure.

AT last we see Shelley plain. Newman Ivey White, Professor of English at Duke University, has written a Shelley biography* superseding all others, including the two-volume Dowden (1886) and the two-volume Peck (1927).

Representatives of thirty-three patriotic societies were present yesterday afternoon at the eighteenth annual Joint Thanksgiving Service at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, attended by a congregation of 2,000 persons.

In the gloom of an overcast day, the Giants flashed their most brilliant performance of the season as they upset the highly favored Redskins yesterday before 46,439 astonished fans at the Polo Grounds, an extraordinary crowd in view of the wretched weather.

LONDON, Nov. 24--Viscount Craigavon, Premier of Northern Ireland, died tonight at his home, Glencraig, near Belfast, at the age of 69. Throughout his long political career he had opposed Home Rule and the idea of a United Irish Republic.

The Greenwich Savings Bank sold to the Claramax Realty Company the seven-story loft building at 130 West Twenty-sixth Street through Isaac Alper, broker. Arnold M. Kashowitz, attorney, represented the buyer and Middlebrook Sincerbeaux acted for the seller.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24--The question, "Shall We Give Full Military Aid (men and ships) to England?" was debated over the radio in Theodore Granik's American Forum of the Air tonight by an author, a publisher, a Senator and a Representative.

Fighting off a spirited last-period attack, the New York Americans defeated the Canadiens of Montreal at Madison Square Garden last night. 2 to 1. The Dutton skaters were more than pleased with the triumph, for it marked their first home success of the current National Hockey League race.

The statement of the British Ambassador, Lord Lothian, that England will need financial aid in 1941 may soon confront this country with a problem that up to the present it has been safely able to ignore or put aside.
VICHY, France, Nov. 24--Some time ago it was announced here that an exchange of art objects had been arranged between the French and Spanish Governments, but no details were given.

SINGAPORE, Straits Settlements, Nov. 24--Leaders of the Chinese government in Chungking are not irked over any proposals respecting Soviet-Japanese appeasement that Adolf Hitler may have made to Premier and Foreign Commissar Vyacheslaff M. Molotoff.
PARIS, Nov. 18 (Delayed; via Berlin) (AP)--Drastic new rationing regulations announced today and effective until Jan. 1 further reduced Parisians' food allowances.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 (AP)--The Supreme Court may act tomorrow on litigation which Georgia officials contend involves "the efficacy of the national system of unemployment compensation."

For the first time in the nation's peace time history, groups of men will start compulsory military training today in camps throughout the country. A total of 18,700 will report for duty today and by the end of June 789,000 will be under arms.

One American short-course record was broken and another equaled by Women's Swimming Association of New York competitors in an A.A.U. water carnival held in the 60-foot pool of the Hotel Sutton yesterday.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 24-- Warner Brothers has announced the purchase of "George Washington Slept Here," current Broadway comedy by George S. Kaufman and Moss Hart, dealing with events in a Bucks County, Pa., farmhouse which contains a bedstead where George Washington reputedly spent a night.

VICHY, France, Nov. 24--British airplanes flew over Marseille last night and dropped bombs. Four women were killed and five injured. Apologies and reparation have been demanded of the British Government.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 (UP)-- Growers of burley, dark fire-cured and dark air-cured tobacco voted in Saturday's referendum to impose Federal quota restrictions on marketings for the next three years, the Department of Agriculture announced tonight.
NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 24--The cotton market here was decidedly more active last week than it had been in some time previously and prices were advanced to new highs for the season on all present crop

Bela Bartok, who, with Zoltan Kodaly, stands as one of the two most representative Hungarian composers of this epoch, appeared last night in Town Hall in a concert of music for two pianos, with Ditta Pasztory, Mr. Bartok's pupil and wife.

An anonymous contribution of $10,000 and gifts of $5,000 each from Mrs. James H.R. Cromwell and the John A. Hartford Foundation were announced yesterday by Roy E. Larsen, general chairman of the sixty-second annual United Hospital campaign.

WITH THE GREEK ARMY, in Albania, via Athens, Nov. 24--The residents of Koritza celebrated their "freedom" yesterday when crowds filled the town square and cafes opened after six days, Koritza is returning rapidly to normal. Hundreds of small boys are helping tear down barricades from the main, wide boulevard which the Italians did not wait to defend.

Prominent food manufacturers arriving here to attend the opening sessions today of the thirty-second annual convention of the Associated Grocery Manufacturers of America in the Waldorf-Astoria declared yesterday that there were ample food supplies for the United States in any wartime emergency and that prices to consumers would not advance for at least six months or a year.

Gift merchandise and heavy outdoor apparel accounted for the bulk of buying in the New York wholesale market last week. There was some purchasing of advance Spring apparel and goods for January sales events. In the coat market reversibles were purchased in volume for gift selling.
It is reported that swagger sticks will be allowed to make their appearance in our new national Army.

LONDON, Monday, Nov. 25-- Widespread raids by the Royal Air Force throughout Saturday night at points as far apart as Berlin, Turin, Italy; Vikero, Norway; Channel ports of the Continent, and the Krupp works at Essen were reported by the British Air Ministry.

FORT McCLELLAN, Ala., Nov. 24--It is now possible to report that the case of Private First Class Mouse, Company C, 165th Infantry, which for a month has threatened to cause internal strife in the "Fighting Irish," has been settled amicably.

Had Artur Rubinstein been a painter he probably would have specialized in murals. The pianist, who gate his second recital of the season last night in Carnegie Hall, delights in the grand line, the widest possible range of color effects.

OTTAWA, Nov. 24--Not a single food parcel has yet reached any of the 44,000 British prisoners of war in Germany despite the fact that the Canadian War Prisoners Parcels Committee is prepared to send 10,000 parcels a week, it was revealed here today.

ATHENS, Nov. 24--Italian forces were reported tonight, in helterskelter, retreat on all sectors and fleeing so rapidly that they left behind them a wealth of war booty, most of which the Greeks were unable to pick up--so swift were they in pursuit of the enemy.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, Nov. 24 (AP) --The military attache of the German Embassy left for Berlin by plane today, unofficially reported to be carrying confidential memoranda on the results of a conference which Ambassador Franz von Papen had with the Turkish Foreign Minister yesterday.

CHICAGO, Nov. 24--Easiness in grains had a sentimental effect on operations in lard last week and, with scattered liquidation by holders of the December and January contracts, prices averaged slightly lower.

CAMDEN, N.J., Nov. 24--Champion Flornell Glamorous, whippet owned by the Mardomere Kennels of Glen Head, L.I., and shown by Percy Roberts of Noroton, Conn., captured the chief prize among 718 dogs today at the Camden County kennel Club's ninth annual fixture.

Last week the Irving Fisher index of wholesale commodity prices remained unchanged at 84.5. There were very few changes, and those that did occur were minor in extent. The only individual changes worthy of note were the rise in oranges and the decrease in live poultry.
CHICAGO, Nov. 24--Staging their finest offense of the season, the Chicago Bears overwhelmed the Cleveland Rams today, 47 to 25, in a National Football League game before 20,717 spectators.

DALLAS, Texas, Nov. 24 (AP)--A 5-inch coat of ice was thickening on communications lines in the isolated Texas Panhandle tonight, while in East Central Texas vast lakes formed on thousands of acres of fertile farm lands and torrential rains continued to fall.

Mr. and Mrs. H. Lester Cuddihy of 24 East Seventy-third Street have sent out invitations for the marriage of their daughter, Miss Mary Jane Cuddihy, to James Butler MacGuire, which will take place the morning of Dec. 10 in the Roman Catholic Church of St. Vincent Ferrer, Lexington Avenue and Sixty-sixth Street.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 24--Accurate passing by Ed Danowski and Grenny Lansdell enabled the Jersey City Giants tc score a 17-to-0 victory over the Newark Bears in an American Pro Football Association game today before more than 10,000 spectators.
BOSTON, Nov. 24--Dr. Ernest Amory Codman, bone specialist and consulting surgeon at Massachusetts General Hospital, died yesterday at his home on Green Street, Ponkapoa, at the age of 70.

HAVANA, Nov. 24--Some 25,000 workers marched to the palace this morning to present demands to President Fulgenico Batista that the Confederation of Cuban workers receive legal status and labor gains in the new Constitution which is to be put into effect immediately.

Columbia University has awarded honorary degrees to an American physicist, a British legal scholar, a French literary historian and an Hungarian composer, it was announced yesterday. At a special university convocation this afternoon at 4 o'clock in the rotunda of the Low Memorial Library, Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of the university, will present the degrees.

DETROIT, Nov. 24--The Green Bay Packers today rolled up their biggest score since entering the National Football League in 1919 by swamping the Detroit Lions, 50 to 7. The triumph kept alive Green Bay's hopes of overtaking the Chicago Bears in the fight for the Western division title now held by the Packers. It was the worst de feat in the history of the Detroit club.

IT'S odd to look over the Yale--deep blue is the color--record for the season and note that the only team Yale defeated was Dartmouth, the outfit that pulled the big surprise on the allconquering (up to that fifth down) Cornell team. Of course, Penn gave Cornell another defeat but that could not be called any surprise. Penn rooters considered it merely carrying out a well-planned program. But they did shave it pretty thin, at that.

As the Greeks continued to drive the Italians back deeper into Albania yesterday, word came from Athens of the arrival of both British air and land reinforcements. A contingent that landed at an unnamed port received a joyous reception from Greek civilians.

With the exception of a sharp break on Wednesday, prices of cotton moved upward last week. Spot cotton was at the highest level since the beginning of the season and all active futures made new highs for the lives of the contracts.

Fifteen hundred delegates of Jewish labor, fraternal and civic organizations attending the sixteenth annual convention of the National Labor Committee for Palestine at the Hotel Astor voted yesterday to raise $1,000,000 during the coming year for the support of Histadrut, Jewish Labor Federation of Palestine, as part of the upbuilding of Palestine as a Jewish national home.

The Whitney Museum's 1940 annual exhibition of contemporary American painting opened with a preview last night for the artists and their friends. It opens to the public today and will be current until Jan. 8. As a convenience for Art Week visitors, the museum, at 10 West Eighth Street, will be open not only during the day but also from 6 to 10 in the evening, through Friday.

The preparatory campaign leading to what may prove the most important ring engagement in his boxing career ended yesterday for Lee Savold. The Des Moines heavyweight finished training for his twelve-round bout with Billy Conn, world light-heavyweight champion, in Madison Square Garden Friday night.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26--The government intends to keep defense plants open and undamaged, President Roosevelt declared today following a White House conference devoted to ways and means of preventing strikes which would interfere with production of war materials.

The international situation again yesterday had the financial community baffled, and the stock market held to its irregular pace in another dull session. Intervals of strength punctuated the day, but the rallying efforts failed to carry through, and final quotations were irregularly lower than on Monday.

The board of directors of the Republic Steel Corporation declared a dividend of 40 cents a share on the common stock yesterday, payable Deo. 27 to stock of record Dec. 10, the first common dividend paid by the corporation since 1930, when $1.24 a share was paid. Since the company was formed in that year, these are the only common dividends it has ever declared.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 26-- The Westchester County Board of Acquisition and Contract is seeking an option on the 186-acre Reynolds tract near Valhalla so the county may acquire the property if the Federal Government provides funds for its development into a county airport, County Executive William F. Bleakley announced today.

The Westchester division of the Women's Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association completed its Class B interclub team tournament yesterday, when the Bronxville Field Club defeated Ardsley, 4 to 1, and the Greenwich Field Club won by default from Apawamis.

Nearly one-fourth of the selective service men from New York City and its environs examined yesterday for induction into the Army were found to be physically incapable of military service, it was learned last night.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26--President Roosevelt signed today the Ramspeck bill which permits the Chief Executive to put under the merit system about 200,000 employes of "temporary" government agencies, if they pass noncompetitive examinations. A large proportion of the jobs affected have been subject to patronage.

A three-goal burst in the second period proved more than enough for the Toronto Maple Leafs to sub due the New York Rangers in their National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden last night. The high-flying visitors accounted for one more tally in the third period for good measure, and this closing contribution enabled them to skate off with a 4-to-2 advantage.

The arrival yesterday of approximately $4,700,000 of gold from Argentina was reported unofficially. The gold, which consisted of 115 boxes of coin, was reported consigned to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.
